- - Standard Template - - Clean Clean false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE Hi Joel, Great to hear from you. Thanks so much for the feedback. If their client’s preference has to do with needing to pay a small business MBO is classified as a small business so we could easily meet that preference/requirement for them. Additionally, consultants can always hold the legal agreement if they (or their client) prefer. We would just ask that they sign this form <http://info.mbopartners.com/rs/mbo/images/MBO_Contract_Acknowledgement_Form.pdf> so they are aware of the risks of MBO not holding the contract. The client would also have to be comfortable making payment to MBO without a contract. I hope these things address some of the concerns, please let me know if you have any additional questions. We so appreciate your referrals! From: Joel Dubow [mailto:jdubow@msn.com] Sent: Wednesday, December 19, 2012 12:06 PM To: Sara Conde Subject: RE: Discover MBO Partners' New Referral Program! Hi Sara:
This is a good idea and good program. I wish you and MBO a lot of success with it and will try to participate as well.
On that note, when I've referred some small business colleagues to MBO regarding their looking for people to help on projects, I sometimes get a response that "they prefer to be able to get bills from individual consultants and pay individual consultants instead of sub contractors, which is how they view MBO. It has something to do with Small business innovative research grants (SBIR) and related small business contracts. I don't know if it is possible, but if you had a non-circumvent agreement with the appropriate clients and an agreement to have reimbursements/fees deposited into the clients MBO accounts, then could you circumvent this limitation and the consultant bill the company with MBO being the agent of the consultant. This might not enable the client to get certain benefits of working through MBO, but it might lead to more and easier business.
all the best
